prompt: <description>**Construct a 3D model of a rectangular prism with a cutout on one side, creating a smaller rectangular prism inside.** **Part 1** Begin by creating a new coordinate system with euler angles {0.0, 0.0, -90.0} and translation vector {0.0, 0.3351, 0.0}. Create a sketch on a plane defined by the coordinate system. The sketch contains one face with one loop. The loop consists of 1. Line 1: Start Point {0.0, 0.0}, End Point {0.75, 0.0} 2. Line 2: Start Point {0.75, 0.0}, End Point {0.75, 0.495} 3. Line 3: Start Point {0.75, 0.495}, End Point {0.6043, 0.495} 4. Line 4: Start Point {0.6043, 0.495}, End Point {0.6043, 0.2379} 5. Line 5: Start Point {0.6043, 0.2379}, End Point {0.1457, 0.2379} 6. Line 6: Start Point {0.1457, 0.2379}, End Point {0.1457, 0.495} 7. Line 7: Start Point {0.1457, 0.495}, End Point {0.0, 0.495} 8. Line 8: Start Point {0.0, 0.495}, End Point {0.0, 0.0} Scale the sketch by a factor of 0.75. Transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D Sketch using the euler angles and translation vector defined in the coordinate system. Extrude the 3D sketch to a depth of 0.3351 units in the direction of the normal. This results in a 3D model of a rectangular prism with various shapes and features attached to it. The length is approximately 0.75 units, the width is approximately 0.34 units, and the height is approximately 0.75 units. **Part 2** Create a new coordinate system with euler angles {0.0, 0.0, 0.0} and translation vector {0.6043, 0.0944, 0.495}. Create a sketch on a plane defined by the coordinate system. The sketch contains one face with one loop. The loop consists of 1. Line 1: Start Point {0.0, 0.0}, End Point {0.1457, 0.0} 2. Line 2: Start Point {0.1457, 0.0}, End Point {0.1457, 0.1485} 3. Line 3: Start Point {0.1457, 0.1485}, End Point {0.0, 0.1485} 4. Line 4: Start Point {0.0, 0.1485}, End Point {0.0, 0.0} Do not extrude this sketch. Instead, use it to cut into the existing 3D model. This will create a cutout in the shape of a smaller rectangular prism. The cutout has a length of approximately 0.15 units, a width of approximately 0.15 units, and a height of approximately 0.17 units. The final shape is a 3D model of a rectangular prism with a cutout on one side, creating a smaller rectangular prism inside. The overall length is approximately 0.75 units, the width is approximately 0.34 units, and the height is approximately 0.75 units.</description>

prompt: <description>**Instructions for Part 1** Construct a 3D model of a rectangular prism with a smaller rectangular prism on top of it. Begin by creating a new coordinate system. 1. **Define Coordinate System** The euler angles for the coordinate system are [0.0, 0.0, -90.0] and the translation vector is [0.0, 0.1312, 0.0]. This configuration defines the orientation and placement of the 2D sketch plane. 2. **Create 2D Sketch** Next, create a 2D sketch on the plane defined by the coordinate system. The sketch is divided into two faces. **Face 1** - Loop 1 - Line 1: Start Point [0.0, 0.1082]; End Point [0.2769, 0.1082] - Line 2: Start Point [0.2769, 0.1082]; End Point [0.2769, 0.4264] - Line 3: Start Point [0.2769, 0.4264]; End Point [0.0, 0.4264] - Line 4: Start Point [0.0, 0.4264]; End Point [0.0, 0.1082] **Face 2** - Loop 1 - Line 1: Start Point [0.4871, 0.0]; End Point [0.75, 0.0] - Line 2: Start Point [0.75, 0.0]; End Point [0.75, 0.3563] - Line 3: Start Point [0.75, 0.3563]; End Point [0.4871, 0.3563] - Line 4: Start Point [0.4871, 0.3563]; End Point [0.4871, 0.0] Note that each loop is a closed sequence of lines. 3. **Scale the 2D Sketch** Apply a scaling factor of 0.75 to the 2D sketch. This is specified by the `sketch_scale` parameter. 4. **Transform 2D Sketch into 3D Sketch** Transform the scaled 2D sketch into a 3D sketch using the specified euler angles and translation vector. 5. **Extrude the 2D Sketch to Generate the 3D Model** Extrude the 2D sketch along the normal direction by a depth of 0.1312 units. Additionally, since the `extrude_depth_opposite_normal` value is 0, no extrusion occurs in the opposite direction. 6. **Perform Boolean Operation** Finally, integrate this part with preceding CAD models using the "NewBodyFeatureOperation" (i.e., create a new solid body). Repeat the above steps for any additional parts in the assembly. Dimensions for the intermediate part and the final shape are as follows: - Part 1: length - 0.75 units, width - 0.1312 units, height - 0.75 units - Final shape: length - 0.75 units, width - 0.1312 units, height - 0.75 units Confidence: 90%</description>

prompt: <description>Part 1: Creating the Base of the Metal Box The first part of the assembly is a rectangular metal box with a cylindrical hole on one side. We will begin by creating the base of the box. Creating the Coordinate System 1. Create a new coordinate system with the following properties: - Euler Angles: [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] - Translation Vector: [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] Drawing the Sketch 1. Create a new sketch on the X-Y plane of the coordinate system. 2. Draw the outer rectangle by creating lines between the following points: - Line 1: [0.0682, 0.0] to [0.4773, 0.0] - Line 2: [0.4773, 0.0] to [0.5455, 0.0682] - Line 3: [0.5455, 0.0682] to [0.5455, 0.6818] - Line 4: [0.5455, 0.6818] to [0.0682, 0.6818] - Line 5: [0.0682, 0.6818] to [0.0682, 0.0682] 3. Draw the inner rectangle by creating lines between the following points: - Line 1: [0.1909, 0.0955] to [0.3545, 0.0955] - Line 2: [0.3545, 0.0955] to [0.3818, 0.1227] - Line 3: [0.3818, 0.1227] to [0.3818, 0.2318] - Line 4: [0.3818, 0.2318] to [0.3545, 0.2591] - Line 5: [0.3545, 0.2591] to [0.1909, 0.2591] - Line 6: [0.1909, 0.2591] to [0.1636, 0.2318] - Line 7: [0.1636, 0.2318] to [0.1636, 0.15] - Line 8: [0.1636, 0.15] to [0.1909, 0.1227] 4. Draw the cylindrical hole by creating an arc with the following properties: - Center: [0.2727, 0.5727] - Radius: 0.075 5. Close the loop for the cylindrical hole. Scaling the Sketch 1. Scale the entire sketch by a factor of 0.75. Transforming the Sketch into 3D 1. Define the transformation by specifying the euler angles and the translation vector of the coordinate system. Extruding the Sketch 1. Extrude the outer rectangle along the Z-axis by 0.1364 (which is the height of the box). Applying the Boolean Operation 1. Perform a New Body Feature Operation to create a new solid body from the extruded shape. The base of the metal box is now created. Continue with the following parts to complete the metal box with a cylindrical hole.</description>

<description>Part 1: Rectangular Prism with Curved Top and Bottom The first part of the CAD model is a rectangular prism with curved top and bottom surfaces. Creating the Coordinate System Begin by creating a new coordinate system with the following properties: * Euler Angles: [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] * Translation Vector: [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] Generating the Sketch Next, create a sketch on the X-Y plane of the coordinate system. The sketch consists of two loops: an outer loop and an inner loop. 1. **Outer Loop** * Line 1: Start Point [0.0, 0.0], End Point [0.4045, 0.0] * Line 2: Start Point [0.4045, 0.0], End Point [0.4045, 0.75] * Line 3: Start Point [0.4045, 0.75], End Point [0.0, 0.75] * Line 4: Start Point [0.0, 0.75], End Point [0.0, 0.0] 2. **Inner Loop** * Line 1: Start Point [0.0091, 0.0091], End Point [0.3955, 0.0091] * Line 2: Start Point [0.3955, 0.0091], End Point [0.3955, 0.7409] * Line 3: Start Point [0.3955, 0.7409], End Point [0.0091, 0.7409] * Line 4: Start Point [0.0091, 0.7409], End Point [0.0091, 0.0091] Ensure that all lines are connected to form a closed loop. Transforming the Sketch into a 3D Model Now, scale the sketch by a factor of 0.75 using the `sketch_scale` parameter. After scaling the sketch, apply the following transformation: * Euler Angles: [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] (or no rotation) * Translation Vector: [0.0, 0.0, 0.0] (or no translation) This transformation will maintain the sketch in the X-Y plane without rotation. Extruding the Sketch Finally, extrude the sketch along the normal direction by 0.1136 units, creating the 3D model for the first part. This extrusion forms a rectangular prism with curved top and bottom surfaces, matching the specified dimensions provided in the description. The first part is now complete. Continue building the remaining parts of the CAD model accordingly, following the prescribed format and instructions.</description>
